intro: Brachistus lanceolatus, commonly known as the narrowleaf brachistus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations such as reduced leaf size to minimize water loss. Its small, lance-shaped leaves and yellow-orange flowers make it a distinctive species within its habitat. Brachistus lanceolatus is often found in rocky soils and is considered a minor component of desert ecosystems.
